content: The Federal Employees Leave Sharing Act of 1993, also known as the "Federal Employees Leave Sharing Act," extends programs by amending the duration from 5 years to 10 years. It also grants authority to transfer sick leave. The Federal Employees Leave Sharing Act of 1993 extends programs by amending the duration from 5 years to 10 years and grants authority to transfer sick leave under specific conditions. The Federal Employees Leave Sharing Act of 1993 extends programs by amending the duration from 5 years to 10 years and grants authority to transfer sick leave under specific conditions. Sick leave received under this subchapter may not be used before the exhaustion requirement under section 6333(b) has been met and shall not be considered used before all transferred annual leave has been exhausted. Nothing in this section affects the maximum amount of sick leave or annual leave that may be accrued by a leave recipient while using leave received under this subchapter for a medical emergency. Title 5, United States Code, is amended to include sick leave in addition to annual leave. The Leave Bank Program is modified to allow for sick leave under specific conditions. The program allows for the contribution and use of sick leave in addition to annual leave, with terms and conditions similar to those for annual leave. Sick leave can be contributed to meet certain requirements and cannot be used before meeting exhaustion requirements. Amendments are made to sections 6370(a) and 6372(c)(1) of title 5, United States Code, regarding the use of annual or sick leave. The table of sections for chapter 63 of title 5, United States Code, is amended by inserting a new item after section 6338. The table of sections for chapter 63 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include a new item for sick leave. Regulations for the amendments made shall be effective by January 31, 1994.
